This function won't behave correctly for all inputs.Consider the input addr=10.0.2.128/25 and plen=24, for example. This function would return 10.0.2.0/24, which encompasses the input subnet.

A better way to implement this would be to take addr.address(), and do an offset of -Math.pow(2, 32 - plen). This will move you far enough away from the subnet that, when you truncate the bits below with createCIDR(), the resulting subnet will not overlap with the input.

You should make sure to add some decrementSubnet() tests to util-alloc.test.js for these kinds of situations.
Fixed, but at the incrementSubnet and decrementSubnet levels, by creating a new CIDR with a (potentially) smaller prefix (if necessary).

Let's avoid moving the addresses back and forth between strings and objects, and just use objects in all of the new code as much as possible. For any constant addresses or subnets you want to compare against, just create another constant ip6addr object above, and use .compare() here.
Done

Please make these addresses constants above, like IP_10_0_0_0 and others are.

We're also still moving back and forth between strings and objects in decrementSubnet and incrementSubnet, where we convert it back to a string at the very end. Let's keep that an object, and then make allocateSubnet() in lib/models/network.js always return an object so that we don't need to call createCIDR() in the createNetwork() pipeline.
Done

This has a similar issue. Consider the input addr=10.0.2.0/25 and plen=24. This would return 10.0.2.0/24, which would encompass the input subnet, and therefore be overlapping.

A better way to do this would be to offset the subnet's .address() by Math.pow(2, 32 - subnet.prefixLength()) + Math.pow(2, 32 - plen). This would, once the trailing bits are truncated, give you the next non-overlapping subnet of plen size.

You should make sure to add some incrementSubnet() tests for these kinds of cases.
Fixed, but at the incrementSubnet and decrementSubnet levels, by creating a new CIDR with a (potentially) smaller prefix (if necessary).

Please add tests for these two functions where the input subnet is less than and greater than the requested prefix length.

I mistakenly applied Math.min() to the desired prefix. The intent was to use Math.min() to choose the smaller prefix and create an adjusted CIDR that had the same address but a (potentially) smaller prefix. This way the increment/decrement logic in incSubImpl and decSubImpl would not create overlapping subnets. But clearly there is a mismatch between the intent and manifestation here. Fixed.
We still need tests for input subnets where the prefix length is less than the target prefix length. When you add some, please make sure to add them with several example lengths.

Ok, quick update: instead of finding just 1 gap and trying to use it, it is a better idea to walk the entire stream, and save all gaps in a list.

Reasoning: Once the race-condition handling we depend on gets implemented (NAPI-435), we can fail an allocation. Instead of passing this error on to sdc-docker, we should handle it ourselves and allocate a different gap. It is wasteful to walk the stream on each failure, so we should have a list of gaps that we can try to allocate. And if they all fail, we should re-walk the stream.
Yeah, this seems fine if we are saving a list of gaps. Will fix.
Ditto.

Right, sn1 is always less than sn2, since we use it on subnets returned by moray, which sorts them in ascending order. Will the assert for clarity.

I don't how this can possibly limit to 10 networks at a time - as listFilteredNetworks makes no use of copyOpts.params (or maybe listFilteredNetworks should?).

Seems like "limit" should be set on copyOpts and then listFilteredNetworks would set the limit on the moray.listObjs call.
Yeah, forgot to set the limit properly here. The only reason this works at all is because listObjs() sets a default limit, if one is not given. Good catch.

I don't know why this is trying to allocate multiple subnets.

I would prefer this to just find one subnet and abort (stop further searching).

Note: I know there is another ticket to address race collisions, but I don't see why there would be changes here to support that. For a race collision avoidance, I would expect that would work similar to a generator - where you call "next()" only if you want more objects (which in turn may perform more moray searches to fetch N at a time).

TLDR: good idea, I'll fix it.

I see what you're saying. We had a discussion and settled on the list-of-subnets strategy *initially*. But the generator-notion that you describe is logically equivalent and more efficient. So I'll change the code implement a transform-stream on top of the LOMstream/pair-stream. This will let us automatically pause and resume the stream upon hitting a high water mark. Ultimately, the callback would call `read()` once instead of getting the first elem of the `subnets` array. Internally, we will -- for each gap -- return a list of up to 16 possible subnets that can live in the gap. This way if an allocation fails, we simply read the stream again in order to retry.
Great - the transform stream sounds good to me :)
I don't think 'copyOpts.params.limit' needs to be set, just 'copyOpts.limit' (from looking at listFilteredNetworks function).
Done

That's correct, except we only want to get a single object (the very first subnet we find). This code is going to look a little different once Cody implements the retry functionality. For now, I just want to implement something that is semantically equivalent to the old changes (allocates a single subnet), but can be easily modified to accommodate retries. This is why the stream-tests _do_ use a for-loop, while this chunk here doesn't.

Using a hard coded limit like this is not how most transform streams work. Generally streams stop writing/pushing when they have exceeded their highwater limit i.e. when self.push() returns false. They begin writing again (from the point they left off) when they see a "drain" event (i.e. when the buffer is emptied).

Currently, if a consumer of this stream is reading the unused subnets, they will get (up to) a batch of 16 between the first two subnets, then a batch of (up to) 16 from the next two subnets, etc... so this stream doesn't actually generate all the available subnets.

Maybe this is fine for the given application - but if so it should be documented that this is not going to generate all available subnets.
Understood. It is very much the intent that we fetch only up to the first 16 in-between subnets. I will document this.

Not sure why this needs to be _newSub2 - why not just use _newSub from this point down?

I've renamed newSub and newSub2. They can't share the same name, since we want to keep track of the most recent _left_ current value and the most recent _right_ current value. I've renamed these to currentSubLeft, and currentSubRight. I've renamed the very first use of _newSub to currentSub. The idea here is to return a stream of available subnets from both the left end and right end of an otherwise gapless stream of pairs.
Hey, thanks for refactoring this. This is much clearer than the single-loop version from before (and now that I think about it, probably faster, too).

Oh man - the same thing is all over the place in NAPI. What a crappy function/API (errors.invalidParam), it just seems to cause confusion.

Why is it 'unknown'? Did you mean 'unused'? Same goes for this test filename.

FYI (this may just be me - so take with a grain a salt), I've been finding the word "unused" jarring to my brain - as it feels like this is referring to something that's unused (i.e. code or objects that are not needed). I think I prefer the word "available" i.e. "find an available subnet" v's "find an unused subnet".
Yeah, 'available' is a much more accurate adjective than 'unused'. And 'unknown' is the result of compulsive tab-completion -- sorry for not noticing this beforehand.
